content.question: Two identical spheres of known mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are attached to opposite ends of a rod of negligible mass. The mass-rod-mass system is spun in the vertical plane and then released so the system falls downward as it rotates, as shown in the figure. Data are collected and shown in the graph of the vertical velocity, <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, of the two spheres as a function of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The positive direction is considered to be downward. A student uses the graph to make three claims. Claim 1: Change in linear momentum of the center of mass of the system from <math alttext="0.0 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="0.5 second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> can be determined. Claim 2: The average applied force exerted on the center of mass of the system from <math alttext="0.0 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="0.5 second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> can be determined. Claim 3: The change in the kinetic energy of the system from <math alttext="0.0 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="0.5 second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> can be determined. Which of the student's claims are correct?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
